playn.core.gl

Class GLShader

  • java.lang.Object
    • playn.core.gl.GLShader
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    IndexedTrisShader, QuadShader

    public abstract class GLShader
extends Object
    Defines the interface to shaders used by the GL core. The general usage contract for a shader is the following series of calls:
    • One or more of the following call pairs:
      prepareTexture(int, int) followed by addQuad(float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float) or addTriangles(playn.core.InternalTransform, float[], int, int, float, float, int[], int, int, int).
    • A call to flush() to send everything to the GPU.
    Because a shader may be prepared multiple times, care should be taken to avoid rebinding the shader program, uniforms, attributes, etc. if a shader is bound again before being flushed. The base implementation takes care of this.

      static interface  GLShader.Attrib
      Provides the ability to bind a vertex attrib array.
      static interface  GLShader.Uniform1f
      Provides the ability to bind a uniform float value.

      Provides the ability to bind a single uniform int.
      static interface  GLShader.Uniform2f
      Provides the ability to bind a uniform float pair.
      static interface  GLShader.Uniform2fv
      Provides the ability to bind a uniform vec2 vector.
      static interface  GLShader.Uniform2i
      Provides the ability to bind a uniform int pair.
      static interface  GLShader.Uniform3f
      Provides the ability to bind a uniform float triple.
      static interface  GLShader.Uniform4f
      Provides the ability to bind a uniform float four-tuple.
      static interface  GLShader.Uniform4fv
      Provides the ability to bind a uniform vec4 vector.
      static interface  GLShader.UniformMatrix4fv
      Provides the ability to bind a uniform matrix4 vector.

        public void addQuad(float m00,

                    float ty,
                    float left,
                    float top,
                    float right,
                    float bottom,
                    float sl,

                    float sr,
                    float sb)
        Adds an axis-aligned quad to the current render operation. left, top, right, bottom define the bounds of the quad. sl, st, sr, sb define the texture coordinates.

      • addTriangles

        public void addTriangles(InternalTransform local,
                         float[] xys,
                         int xysOffset,
                         int xysLen,
                         float tw,
                         float th,
                         int[] indices,
                         int indicesOffset,
                         int indicesLen,
                         int indexBase)
        Adds a collection of triangles to the current render operation.
        Parameters:
        xys - a list of x/y coordinates as: [x1, y1, x2, y2, ...].
        xysOffset - the offset of the coordinates array, must not be negative and no greater than xys.length. Note: this is an absolute offset; since xys contains pairs of values, this will be some multiple of two.
        xysLen - the number of coordinates to read, must be no less than zero and no greater than xys.length - xysOffset. Note: this is an absolute length; since xys contains pairs of values, this will be some multiple of two.
        tw - the width of the texture for which we will auto-generate texture coordinates.
        th - the height of the texture for which we will auto-generate texture coordinates.
        indices - the index of the triangle vertices in the xys array. Because this method renders a slice of xys, one must also specify indexBase which tells us how to interpret indices. The index into xys will be computed as: 2*(indices[ii] - indexBase), so if your indices reference vertices relative to the whole array you should pass xysOffset/2 for indexBase, but if your indices reference vertices relative to the slice then you should pass zero.
        indicesOffset - the offset of the indices array, must not be negative and no greater than indices.length.
        indicesLen - the number of indices to read, must be no less than zero and no greater than indices.length - indicesOffset.
        indexBase - the basis for interpreting indices. See the docs for indices for details.

      • addTriangles

        public void addTriangles(InternalTransform local,
                         float[] xys,
                         float[] sxys,
                         int xysOffset,
                         int xysLen,
                         int[] indices,
                         int indicesOffset,
                         int indicesLen,
                         int indexBase)
        Adds a collection of triangles to the current render operation. See addTriangles(InternalTransform,float[],int,int,float,float,int[],int,int,int) for parameter documentation.
        Parameters:
        sxys - a list of sx/sy texture coordinates as: [sx1, sy1, sx2, sy2, ...]. This must be of the same length as xys.

      • reference

        public void reference()
        Notes that this shader is in use by a layer. This is used for reference counted resource management. When all layers release a shader, it can destroy its shader programs and release the GL resources it uses.

      • release

        public void release()
        Notes that this shader is no longer in use by a layer. This is used for reference counted resource management. When all layers release a shader, it can destroy its shader programs and release the GL resources it uses.

      • clearProgram

        public void clearProgram()
        Destroys this shader's programs and releases any GL resources. The programs will be recreated if the shader is used again. If a shader is used in a Surface, where it cannot be reference counted, the caller may wish to manually clear its GL resources when it knows the shader will no longer be used. Alternatively, the resources will be reclaimed when this shader is garbage collected.
